Description: Mould-made handle of sistrum in glazed composition; votive offering inscribed with two opposing vertical columns of hieroglyphs; text framed by fine vertical lines; glaze well preserved with turquoise as background colour with dark blue for the inscription and vertical lines; slightly chipped.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Musée du Louvre. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This sacred musical instrument was particularly associated to the cult of Egyptian goddesses, notably Hathor, Isis, Bastet or Sekhmet (on sistra, see esp.: Hickmann 1949, 76-103, pl. XLV-LXX; Pinch 1993, 143-146; Ziegler 1979, 31-62; Ziegler 1984). This sistrum is unprovenanced, but must clearly originate from Naukratis according to the inscriptions. Indeed, Hut-neferet (‘The Beautiful-Castle’) was the name of the Egyptian temple of Naukratis (Yoyotte 1993/94, 684). This name is also mentioned on the Ptolemaic obelisk kept in Tanta Museum and on the Saite donation stela kept in Cairo Museum TR 14/2/25/2. Thanks to the inscriptions, it is also possible to date this sistrum to the Ptolemaic Period and more precisely to the reign of Ptolemy II (on this sistrum see: Ziegler 1979, 52, no. 60; Yoyotte 1993/94, 684; Yoyotte 1994-95, 674; De Meulenaere 2001, 36; Guermeur 2005, 127-128). Naukratis provided several examples of sistra, in glazed composition like for this specimen, but also in copper alloy. A second sistrum in glazed composition bears a hieroglyphic inscription mentioning Psamtek III, a short-lived pharaoh of the 26th dynasty (Cairo, Egyptian Museum JE33537).
